ETYMOLOGY: From Old French majesté, from Latin maiestas ('greatness, dignity, sovereignty'), from maiestus ('noble, august'), from magnus ('great').

MEANINGS.POS_TIP: A word (other than a pronoun) used to identify any of a class of people, places, or things (common noun), or to name a particular one of these (proper noun).
MEANINGS.DEF_EN: Impressive dignity, grandeur, or beauty; used especially in reference to royalty.
MEANINGS.DEF_ZH: （用于称呼或指代君主）陛下；（尤指与君主有关的）威严，庄严，崇高
MEANINGS.SENT_EN: Her Majesty the Queen addressed the parliament.
MEANINGS.SENT_ZH: 女王陛下向议会发表了讲话。

MEANINGS.POS_TIP: A word (other than a pronoun) used to identify any of a class of people, places, or things (common noun), or to name a particular one of these (proper noun).
MEANINGS.DEF_EN: The quality of being impressive and grand in appearance, scale, or character.
MEANINGS.SENT_EN: The majesty of the ancient redwood forests was truly breathtaking.
MEANINGS.SENT_ZH: 古老红杉林的宏伟壮丽令人叹为观止。

REGISTER: Formal, often used in official contexts or descriptive writing.
